```markdown
# buffer-alloc-unsafe

A ponyfill for `Buffer.allocUnsafe` for Node.js versions below v7.0.0 and v0.10.0.

This module provides a compatible `allocUnsafe` function for older Node.js versions, ensuring backward compatibility with applications that rely on this function.

## Installation

```bash
npm install --save buffer-alloc-unsafe
```

## Usage

```javascript
const allocUnsafe = require('buffer-alloc-unsafe');

console.log(allocUnsafe(10));
// Output: <Buffer 78 0c 80 03 01 00 00 00 05 00>  (Example output, actual values will vary)

console.log(allocUnsafe(10));
// Output: <Buffer 58 ed bf 5f ff 7f 00 00 01 00> (Example output, actual values will vary)

console.log(allocUnsafe(10));
// Output: <Buffer 50 0c 80 03 01 00 00 00 0a 00> (Example output, actual values will vary)

try {
  allocUnsafe(-10);
} catch (error) {
  console.error(error); // Output: RangeError: "size" argument must not be negative
}
```

## API

### `allocUnsafe(size)`

Allocates a new, *non-zero-filled*, `Buffer` of `size` bytes.

* **`size`**: An integer representing the desired length of the buffer.  Must be a non-negative integer less than or equal to `buffer.kMaxLength`.  Otherwise, a `RangeError` is thrown.


**Important Considerations:**

* This module provides a compatibility layer for older Node.js versions.  For Node.js v7.0.0 and above, use the built-in `Buffer.allocUnsafe` directly.
* The generated buffer will contain *arbitrary* data, not necessarily zeroes.  If you need a zero-filled buffer, use `Buffer.alloc`.


## Related Modules

* [buffer-alloc](https://github.com/LinusU/buffer-alloc): A ponyfill for `Buffer.alloc`.
* [buffer-fill](https://github.com/LinusU/buffer-fill): A ponyfill for `Buffer.fill`.
* [buffer-from](https://github.com/LinusU/buffer-from): A ponyfill for `Buffer.from`.


## Compatibility

This module aims to provide compatibility with Node.js versions that do not have the `Buffer.allocUnsafe` method.  It is particularly useful in projects requiring support for older Node.js versions.  Be sure to check the compatibility matrix of your Node.js environment when using this module.
```
